qas.question: How is sex by God handled in a monotheistic religion?

answers.text: God has no counterpart with which to relate sexually

qas.question: How do polytheistic religions view sex by God or gods?

answers.text: attribute to each of the gods a gender, allowing each to interact with any of the others, and perhaps with humans, sexually

qas.question: What is God's role in the creation of the world?
In what ways can the gender of God be viewed?
What do polytheistic religions assign to their gods?
What role does got serve in a sexual intercourse?

answers.text: the active (as opposed to the receptive) role

qas.question: In which type of religion does God have no sexual partner?
What does western philosophy attribute to each of the gods?
What is the role of God's counterpart in creation?

plausible_answers.text: a literal or an allegorical aspect

qas.question: In what way can the sexuality of God's counterpart be viewed?
How does western philosophy allow God to act with humans?
What does the counterpart of God transcend?

context: The <a4_0>gender<a4_0/> of God may be viewed as either <b9_0>a <a3_0>literal or an allegorical aspect<b9_0/><a3_0/> of a deity who, in classical western philosophy, transcends <b11_0>bodily form<b11_0/>. Polytheistic religions commonly <a1_0>attribute to each of the gods <b7_0>a gender<b7_0/>, allowing each to interact with any of the others, and perhaps with humans, sexually<a1_0/>. In most <a6_0>monotheistic<a6_0/> religions, <a0_0>God has no counterpart with which to relate <b10_0>sexually<b10_0/><a0_0/>. Thus, in classical western philosophy the gender of this one-and-only deity is most likely to be an analogical statement of how humans and God address, and relate to, each other. Namely, God is seen as <a2_0><b8_0>begetter<a2_0/> of the world<b8_0/> and revelation which corresponds to <a5_0>the active (as opposed to the receptive) role<a5_0/> in sexual intercourse.
